title: Make reducer generics more generic
body:
This enforces that the action parameter extends `Action` for strongly typed implementations, and defaults to `AnyAction` for the case where an action may not be explicitly typed.

Enhancement to #2467 
Addresses an issue discovered in a failed build for DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped#17777

title: Feature/typescript todo example
body:
Typescript Todos Example - ticket: https://github.com/reactjs/redux/issues/2489

---

Hi guys,

not sure if there are some fans of TypeScript ‚úåÔ∏è - but definitely it's good alternative to Flow. For Redux there is already Flow todos example - but **TypeScript example project** is **missing**, and you need to search it in alternative sources.

So I thought, might be nice idea to create todos also in TypeScript! üòè

Sub-project is based on Flow example, rewritten to typescript, added required typings and changed [React create app scripts to support typescript](https://github.com/wmonk/create-react-app-typescript).

Hope this might be good start for new guys adopting redux in TypeScript. And for experienced TypeScript devs to get always fresh ideas from this example (maintained by redux community).

Soo.. what do you think?

title: Provide correct test description for 2 of the tests
Add library size check in CI
body: This will help in **keeping** redux tiny. It's basically, this in the terminal: ``` PASS ./dist/redux.min.js: 2.18kB < maxSize 2.5kB gzip ``` and something like this in the pull request: 1. Setting the file and threshold: The config sits inside `package.json`, the maxSize is set to 2.5kB right now. You can add multiple files here. ([docs](https://github.com/siddharthkp/bundlesize/blob/master/README.md#configuration)) 2. Authorize bundlesize: `bundlesize` needs access to github API with scope `repo:status`, You can follow the [steps here](https://github.com/siddharthkp/bundlesize/blob/master/README.md#2-build-status) -------- Changes made: - [x] Add bundlesize as dev dependency - [x] Add config for bundlesize - [x] Move `build` before `test` in `prepare` script - [x] Split `test` script to `test:unit` and `test:size` - [ ] Add github token to travis environment variables (you have to do this) Happy to hear your feedback üòÑ

title: Update AsyncActions.md
Updated 1 createStore's test description
Remove usage of `check:src` npm script from contributing.md
body:
CONTRIBUTING.md [contains](https://github.com/reactjs/redux/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#testing-and-linting) missed `check:src` script, that was removed in https://github.com/reactjs/redux/commit/35cb4a914ea501c13534888eb01103d756e3619e. 

In this PR I'm adding `check` npm script, that includes lint and test and fix CONTRIBUTING.md.

title: Can't export combineReducers with TypeScript as AnyAction is private
body:
**Do you want to request a *feature* or report a *bug*?**  
Bug

**What is the current behavior?**

When I try to export `combineReducers`, TypeScript throw the following error:
> error TS4082: Default export of the module has or is using private name 'AnyAction'.

**If the current behavior is a bug, please provide the steps to reproduce and if possible a minimal demo of the problem via https://jsfiddle.net or similar.**

I simply export `combineReducers`

```
export default combineReducers({
  myReducerOne: oneReducer,
  myReducerTwo: twoReducer,
});
```

**What is the expected behavior?**

No error from typescript, we should be allowed to export `combineReducers`

**Which versions of Redux, and which browser and OS are affected by this issue? Did this work in previous versions of Redux?**

Typescript 2.4.1
Redux 3.7.2

I noticed the `@private` flag has been added yesterday as a comment in the definition code

```
/**
 * An Action type which accepts any other properties.
 * This is mainly for the use of the `Reducer` type.
 * This is not part of `Action` itself to prevent users who are extending `Action.
 * @private
 */
export interface AnyAction extends Action {
  // Allows any extra properties to be defined in an action.
  [extraProps: string]: any;
}
```

Typescript doesn't like this at all.
Any reason why this is flagged as private?

title: File reducers not found at index.js of todo example
body:
This line `import reducer from './reducers'` from [index.js](https://github.com/reactjs/redux/blob/master/examples/todos/src/index.js) is not finding the file reducers.js because don't exist. 

What exist is a folder called reducers, not a file.

**Error:**

`Failed to compile
./src/index.js
Module not found: Can't resolve './reducers' in 'D:\pai\code\juridico-blog\src'
This error occurred during the build time and cannot be dismissed.`

title: Remove `src` directory from npm package
body: `./src` directory is not used in npm package, only `./es` (as source for ES-module), `./lib` (as a source for old js syntax module) and `./dist` (as UMD module), so it can be removed. It reduces size of installed package by 21.4%

title: Allow ReduxStore to callback subscribers event methods, not only the onStateChange(StoreState).
body:
**Do you want to request a *feature* or report a *bug*?**  

Request a feature

Hi there, I am working with an implementation of Redux for Android. The Kotlin library API is the same API as defined by the redux specs, no difference other than the language. I am having some problems with detecting specific Store events. Normally a component has only one interaction with the store, this is through the event onStoreChange(State currentState). With Presentational components there is no problem, because they only render the component props into the view. But, what happen if I have a Container component that needs to add/remove child components depending on a Store specific event.
In other words, the only information that a Store gives to a subscriber is the Store State itself, we can compare the previous state against the current state to determine the event that just happened, but its high performance. Another option to detect a specific event could be having an event map in the State and mark them with true/false as they happen. Then the subscribed component will check this map and act accordingly to the active event. 
However, I consider that the easiest way to inform a component about specific events in the State is to subscribe an StoreEventsListener object from the component, that will receive callbacks associated with specific Store events. 
Is this something that breaks the rules of redux?

title: redux cannot be AoT compiled by angular-cli
How to define the initialState correct for a react component?
body:
For example, an ArticleList component, at first, there is no data;

the state maybe something like: 
```javascript
state = {
  articleList: [],
  isFetching: false
}
```
At first, i want it to render to nothing(null).

If i check the isFetching is true, then render null.But it will also render a loading spinner base on that isFetching state.

If i check the articleList.length === 0, then render null. But it also want to display some user friendly message base on that state.

So if there should be some other property to determine that the initial render result is null?

Is there any `best practise` to this situation?

title: Redux : Testing async functions
body:
Hi,

I am trying to test Async Action Creators as per the documentation described [here](http://redux.js.org/docs/recipes/WritingTests.html#): 

I am using 'nock' to mock my api call.

But instead of returning the mocked response, when I dispatch the action, It is calling the actual "fetch" call in my action code.

I am using the global fetch api for my api calls.

Any help will be appreciated as I am currently stuck here.

title: TypeScript: Can't use strict custom Action types any more
Remove @private flag on AnyAction type definition
Update UsageWithReactRouter.md
"dispatch" passed to middlewares only passes through first argument
body:
**Do you want to request a *feature* or report a *bug*?** Bug


**What is the current behavior?**
Right now a "dispatch" function that's passed to middlewares passes through only the first argument.

From `applyMiddleware.js`:
```javascript
    var middlewareAPI = {
      getState: store.getState,
      dispatch: (action) => dispatch(action)
    }
```
I have a custom middleware that accepts a dispatch call with 2 arguments. This works fine in, say, `mapDispatchToProps` (from `react-redux`) as it uses `store.dispatch`, but in `dispatch` calls in redux-thunk, the second argument disappears.

**What is the expected behavior?**
All the arguments are passed to the dispatch:
```javascript
    var middlewareAPI = {
      getState: store.getState,
      dispatch: (...args) => dispatch(...args)
    }
```

There are ways to work around it (you can put all the arguments in an array or object), additional arguments can also be stripped by any middleware in middlewares chain, but still it would make things more consistent.

If it makes sense I can submit a PR.

title: Updated the definition of 'Reducer' and 'Dispatch' for TypeScript 2.3+
